I think calling two mod and then bind it input/output separately even if it is the "same" symbol create two different network. Is there a way correct this ? (maybe I am doing something wrong). 
If it's not, is it possible to train only  one input and one output  a network which have two intput/output ? I did not find a topic about it.

The .rec file that I am getting is much bigger than the original dataset. My dataset is ~ 8GB and when I encode 1% of the data my .rec file would have a size of 2.3G
Thanks @piiswrong !!!

You need to compile with caffe plugin to enable Caffeop

```sh
git clone --recursive https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet
cd mxnet
cp make/osx.mk config.mk
make -j$(nproc)
make rpkg
```

AFAIK, there isn't a C++ tutorial.
Are you trying to read records from a file in recordio format from C++?
Have you looked at how the python binding is implemented? https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/recordio.py

It simply delegates to the appropriate C++ API calls.

For resnext101-64x4d use --rgb-mean 123.68,116.779,103.939.
I am not sure about resnext101-32x4d and resnext50-32x4d though, since I did not train them.
For resnext101-32x4d and resnext50-32x4d we don't need to do mean subtraction, cuz batch norm op after input data.  plz set --rgb-mean 0,0,0

With some modification to #7059 (see #7093), I was able to achieve a test ppl of 73.03 with hidden size of 650 and 71.74 with hidden size of 1500, with tied weights and variational drop of 0.5 on outputs and 0.5 on states. Compared to 75.96 and 72.30 in pytorch with the same setting with regular dropout.

I tried your code above. 
global_pooling_feature <- predict(model, X = normed) actually gives the probability vector, as it sums up to one.
I tried using predict(model2, X = normed) and got an error. Can you shed some light on how to obtain the global pooling feature? Thanks.
@kkgadiraju that's awesome, it works!
@piiswrong Thanks for replying! Do you mean uncomment MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/caffe/caffe.mk in config.mk? Cause I have already done this.
I think I have solved it , by removing the superfluous blank in the line USE_CUDA = 1 (in the file of config.mk)

Already enabled
CAFFE_PATH = /home/chidanand/Softwares/MXNET_CAFFE_Integration/caffe-enet/
MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/caffe/caffe.mk

getting the same error. Any suggestions would be helpful.

Thanks for the lead!

 I don't why I had some issues with the git repo clone last time. Finally, I fixed these. I had to edit **osx.mk** to get to work: 

**export CC = clang-omp
export CXX = clang-omp++
export NVCC = nvcc**

and 

#### the additional link flags you want to add
**ADD_LDFLAGS ='-L/usr/local/Cellar/openblas/0.2.19_1/lib'**
#### the additional compile flags you want to add
**ADD_CFLAGS ='-I/usr/local/Cellar/openblas/0.2.19_1/include'**

with OPENMP, OPENCV and openblas (**OPENMP=1, OPENCV=1, USE_BLAS=openblas**). After adding those paths and correctly specifying compilers, it built mxnet. Rest was the same. I just had to reinstall dplyr after this. The issue is solved.

I am sorry that there is a typo:

```r
library(mxnet)
prefix = "Inception-BN"
num.round = 126
model = mx.model.load(prefix, num.round)
internals = model$symbol$get.internals()
fea_symbol = internals[[match("global_pool_output", internals$outputs)]]

model2 <- list(symbol = fea_symbol,
              arg.params = model$arg.params,
              aux.params = model$aux.params)

class(model2) <- "MXFeedForwardModel"

library(imager)

im <- load.image(system.file("extdata/parrots.png", package = "imager"))
plot(im)

preproc.image <- function(im, mean.image) {
  # crop the image
  shape <- dim(im)
  short.edge <- min(shape[1:2])
  xx <- floor((shape[1] - short.edge) / 2)
  yy <- floor((shape[2] - short.edge) / 2)
  croped <- crop.borders(im, xx, yy)
  # resize to 224 x 224, needed by input of the model.
  resized <- resize(croped, 224, 224)
  # convert to array (x, y, channel)
  arr <- as.array(resized) * 255
  dim(arr) <- c(224, 224, 3)
  # subtract the mean
  normed <- arr - mean.img
  # Reshape to format needed by mxnet (width, height, channel, num)
  dim(normed) <- c(224, 224, 3, 1)
  return(normed)
}

mean.img <- 127

normed <- preproc.image(im, mean.img)

global_pooling_feature <- predict(model2, X = normed)
```

After getting the `model2`, you can set the class to be `MXFeedForwardModel` like below:

```r
model2 <- list(symbol = fea_symbol,
              arg.params = model$arg.params,
              aux.params = model$aux.params)

class(model2) <- "MXFeedForwardModel"
```

Did you install swig via brew ?
brew install swig
seems like your swig setup is incomplete.
The perl binding can certainly be compiled on OSX Sierra, not sure about El Capitan but I think they should.

I followed your instructions, but got the following error:
global_pooling_feature <- predict(model2, X = normed)
Error in exec$update.arg.arrays(arg.arrays, match.name, skip.null) : 
  executor.cc:65: RCheck failed: to->containsElementNamed(names[i].c_str()) cannot find key fc1_bias in the array arg.arrays

The image I used was one of the cat/dog images.

Can you try the code below? 

```r
library(mxnet)
prefix = "Inception-BN"
num.round = 126
model = mx.model.load(prefix, num.round)
internals = model$symbol$get.internals()
fea_symbol = internals[[match("global_pool_output", internals$outputs)]]

model$arg.params$fc1_bias <- NULL
model$arg.params$fc1_weight <- NULL

model2 <- list(symbol = fea_symbol,
              arg.params = model$arg.params,
              aux.params = model$aux.params)

class(model2) <- "MXFeedForwardModel"

library(imager)

im <- load.image(system.file("extdata/parrots.png", package = "imager"))
plot(im)

preproc.image <- function(im, mean.image) {
  # crop the image
  shape <- dim(im)
  short.edge <- min(shape[1:2])
  xx <- floor((shape[1] - short.edge) / 2)
  yy <- floor((shape[2] - short.edge) / 2)
  croped <- crop.borders(im, xx, yy)
  # resize to 224 x 224, needed by input of the model.
  resized <- resize(croped, 224, 224)
  # convert to array (x, y, channel)
  arr <- as.array(resized) * 255
  dim(arr) <- c(224, 224, 3)
  # subtract the mean
  normed <- arr - mean.img
  # Reshape to format needed by mxnet (width, height, channel, num)
  dim(normed) <- c(224, 224, 3, 1)
  return(normed)
}

mean.img <- 127

normed <- preproc.image(im, mean.img)

global_pooling_feature <- predict(model2, X = normed)

dim(global_pooling_feature)
# [1]    1    1 1024    1
```

Thank you! It works. Could you explain why adding
model$arg.params$fc1_bias <- NULL
model$arg.params$fc1_weight <- NULL
would help?
@piiswrong anything that should be addressed before merging this?

`fc1_bias` and `fc1_weight` are for the last fully connected layer after pooling. (See
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/symbol_inception-bn.R#L108-L115)

We don't need them if we want to get the pooling result.

I am using MXNET in R. I am trying linear regression output. But I have no convergence when I give more than 2 hidden layers. So I decided to go for pre-training using autoencoders. 
I have initial weights that I obtained by training a denoising autoencoder (from autoencoder package). How do I initialize a model with those weights?

@piiswrong This problem apparently still exists in latest version of MXNet: pattern=".*" only prints weights/biases when using a BucketingModule, but everything if using a regular Module.
@piiswrong This problem apparently still exists in latest version of MXNet: pattern=".*" only prints weights/biases when using a BucketingModule, but everything if using a regular Module.
how to transfer caffe scale layer to mxnet symbol?

Hey guys @piiswrong @mli @tqchen , can anyone have a review on this? This is an update of the pull request #6304 which adds an early stopping class for the training module. This class is capable of stopping the training early by either non-improving training errors or eval errors (if eval data is given). Users can customise the paticen to decide how many rounds of non-improvement can be tolerated. While early stopping happens, models will be saved by enabling the option. 

This is an extention to the current callback apis which can be used very similar to the Speedometer class so that new users should find it very easy.

Thank you!
I hava update my problem, @feiyulv

@madjam  yes I did and I still have the same problem
 `fatal error: hdfs.h: No such file or directory compilation terminated.`

I had this same issue, but for different data.

Initially I tried with a single hidden layer and all outputs gave the mean value.
I scaled the data between 0 and 1 and changed the optimizer from 'sgd' to 'rmsprop'. This improved things a lot.
I could move to two hidden layers now and the results made sense (to an extent).
However when I moved beyond this point I again faced the issue of all outputs having the mean value.
I have now tried initializing different types of weights and that seems to work. specifically the parameter that i used was initializer  = mx.init.normal(0.2) within the mx.model.FeedForward.create() function. 

I am running further tests right now. I will update further on this once I test more number of hidden layers.

Next, I loaded the pre-trained model and trained it on the true data and that seemed to work just fine. I was also able to switch between different output metrics without a problem using this approach. So initialization seems to be somewhat crucial.

@hadjipantelis @chrismoran0124 

This should have been fixed in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6494

The trained model can be saved and loaded as normal R objects.

Below is an example to save a list of models into RDS file.

```r
require(mlbench)
require(mxnet)

data(Sonar, package = "mlbench")

Sonar[,61] <- as.numeric(Sonar[,61])-1
train.ind <- c(1:50, 100:150)
train.x <- data.matrix(Sonar[train.ind, 1:60])
train.y <- Sonar[train.ind, 61]
test.x <- data.matrix(Sonar[-train.ind, 1:60])
test.y <- Sonar[-train.ind, 61]

mx.set.seed(0)

lst_mlp_model <- list()

lst_mlp_model[[1]] <- mx.mlp(train.x, train.y, hidden_node=10, out_node=2, out_activation="softmax",
                             num.round=20, array.batch.size=20, learning.rate=0.07, momentum=0.9, 
                             eval.metric=mx.metric.accuracy, verbose = FALSE)


lst_mlp_model[[2]] <- mx.mlp(train.x, train.y, hidden_node=15, out_node=2, out_activation="softmax",
                             num.round=20, array.batch.size=15, learning.rate=0.07, momentum=0.9, 
                             eval.metric=mx.metric.accuracy, verbose = FALSE)

lst_mlp_model[[3]] <- mx.mlp(train.x, train.y, hidden_node=10, out_node=2, out_activation="softmax",
                             num.round=20, array.batch.size=15, learning.rate=0.01, momentum=0.9, 
                             eval.metric=mx.metric.accuracy, verbose = FALSE)

lst_mlp_model <- lapply(lst_mlp_model, mx.serialize)

save(lst_mlp_model, file = "test.rds")

q("no")

### restart the R session

load("test.rds")

require(mlbench)
require(mxnet)

data(Sonar, package = "mlbench")

Sonar[,61] <- as.numeric(Sonar[,61])-1
train.ind <- c(1:50, 100:150)
train.x <- data.matrix(Sonar[train.ind, 1:60])
train.y <- Sonar[train.ind, 61]
test.x <- data.matrix(Sonar[-train.ind, 1:60])
test.y <- Sonar[-train.ind, 61]

preds <- lapply(lst_mlp_model, function(m) {
  predict(m, test.x)
})

preds
```

@MikeHuYimin I am giving you an example to extract the pooling results in Inception BN.

You can get any internal results using the similar method.

```r
library(mxnet)
prefix = "Inception-BN"
num.round = 126
model = mx.model.load(prefix, num.round)
internals = model$symbol$get.internals()
fea_symbol = internals[[match("global_pool_output", internals$outputs)]]

model$arg.params$fc1_bias <- NULL
model$arg.params$fc1_weight <- NULL

model2 <- list(symbol = fea_symbol,
              arg.params = model$arg.params,
              aux.params = model$aux.params)

class(model2) <- "MXFeedForwardModel"

library(imager)

im <- load.image(system.file("extdata/parrots.png", package = "imager"))
plot(im)

preproc.image <- function(im, mean.image) {
  # crop the image
  shape <- dim(im)
  short.edge <- min(shape[1:2])
  xx <- floor((shape[1] - short.edge) / 2)
  yy <- floor((shape[2] - short.edge) / 2)
  croped <- crop.borders(im, xx, yy)
  # resize to 224 x 224, needed by input of the model.
  resized <- resize(croped, 224, 224)
  # convert to array (x, y, channel)
  arr <- as.array(resized) * 255
  dim(arr) <- c(224, 224, 3)
  # subtract the mean
  normed <- arr - mean.img
  # Reshape to format needed by mxnet (width, height, channel, num)
  dim(normed) <- c(224, 224, 3, 1)
  return(normed)
}

mean.img <- 127

normed <- preproc.image(im, mean.img)

global_pooling_feature <- predict(model2, X = normed)
dim(global_pooling_feature)
# [1]    1    1 1024    1
```

@thatindiandude: Thank you for taking the time to close this! I actually tried this functionality over the weekend and found it fine; even wrote small `caret` test-wrapper around it. The only thing I was perplexed about was as to why the serialisation step is not default in the output of the object. Does it make a difference if the object is serialised or not on other functionality.

Once again thank you for sorting this out. It was a bit headache!

It's better to do this in python with mx.image.
Although this approach will put more pressure on the engine.

A hacky solution is to do some of the argumentations as operators at the beginning of the network.
I was under impression that mx.image is still in the pre-split and send portion of the fit method, right? So it would need to be changed the same way to be able to do hybrid approach.

@hadjipantelis 

The serialization might be time-consuming if the model is quite large with many parameters. This is the main concern.

If you can write a blog or document on using `mxnet` with `caret`, I am quite happy to take it as a vignette.

You can find others from https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/R-package/vignettes

Allowing iterator to return either a single ndarray or a list of ndarray isn't very hard.

On the other hand, this is easier to do with the new gluon interface. Although gluon is currently 10% slower than module

@adamcrussell 
are you using brew or mac ports ?
macports seems to have per language packaging http://blog.jdlh.com/en/2015/01/25/pycdio_install_error_swig/
if you're using macports try 'sudo port install swig-perl'

Still, this is a change to API of iterators (also, you need to provide GPU context to iterators then, that's another change). Would also need a change to other frontends, besides Python. This issue is to gather feedback from the community on how to do it properly (and I agree if iterators will include the splitting code then it may be not very hard to do it).
Did you make clean and make again after enabling it?
The fit logic is already over complicated. We don't want to further complicate it. It's better to write your own training loop for this kind of advanced behavior
@sergeykolychev thanks! that was indeed the problem. you're right, I am using macports. after `port install swig-perl` the problem was resolved and I have no built all the Perl  modules.

@piiswrong I do respect your concerns, but I think early stopping is something quite standard to me and there is currently no way to do it if the users want to use the fit module for training their networks. Making module complicated is definitely something we wish to avoid, but given that early stopping is commonly used, I still think it's reasonable to add few lines of codes. As I said, I recommend to add this feature, but I shall definitely respect your decision. 👍
@adamcrussell cool, thanks, I'll update the docs with this case.
@yzhang87 yes, reset is indeed called automatically. Removed. Thanks!
Yeah I did multiple times make clean && make . Still the same attribute error caffeop not found. Kindly suggest how to proceed since Ian not able to move further
I have same problem, actually, my project is work yesterday,and I can't find the reason.

Yes, it was not added, and I'll pull the request for that,
meanwhile you can use stt_bucketing_module.py and stt_io_bucketingiter.py in https://github.com/samsungsds-rnd/deepspeech.mxnet
and there was a bug fix in bi_graphemes generator, please replace main.py with file in above link also.
Thank you for reporting!

@piiswrong 
For reference, I am using a custom fit method with a monitor installed like this:
```python
# self.module is a BucketingModule
[...]
monitor = mx.monitor.Monitor(
  interval=50 stat_func=None, pattern=".*", sort=True)
self.module.install_monitor(monitor)
[...]
next_data_batch = train_iter.next()
while True:
  [...]
  batch = next_data_batch
  if monitor is not None:
    monitor.tic()
  self.module.forward_backward(batch)
  self.module.update()
  if train_iter.iter_next():
    # pre-fetch next batch
    next_data_batch = train_iter.next()
    self.module.prepare(next_data_batch)
  self.module.update_metric(metric_train, batch.label)
  monitor is not None:
    monitor.toc_print()
```

In fact, 'everything' (including backward arrays) is eventually printed, but not consistently after every 50 batches. My suspicion is that it only prints them 
- either when all submodules (in this case for different sequence lengths) are at least used once
- or only when the default bucket_key module is being used for a batch.

It would be great to have a consistent output printed for every x batches, regardless whether this is a default_bucket_key batch or not.
I think csv isn't a good method. it is about 1.5TB in bin mode.

Have you solved  the accurancy problem?  Slow is the right reuslt, because cudnn doesn't support group convolution, current group conv is done by call cudnn conv `c` times.  'c' is the channel number. Tensorflow has implemented depth-wise conv using cuda kernel, but speed is still not very good.

Let us clarify here, what is the proposal here, is it:

- Data parallel augs(split ahead and have different thread process each split)
- GPU native augs( have gpu to do the job)

In general, I think we could take benefit of the scheduler/engine on tracking some of the dependencies as we did for the GPU trainining, to make the event handling easier whenw e need asynchrous data parallel augs

GPU native augs and actually even more - as I said the augmentations I'm doing are actually pretty minimal and most of the time is spent on JPEG decode. We think about different ways to speed up decoding - hybrid pipeline (Huffman decode on CPU, DCT on GPU), moving to video i-frames and use hardware decoder for them etc.

metric is in principle separate from loss. You can use all kinds of metrics to measure classification accuracy and you can use all kinds of loss to optimize classifier. They are not necessarily connected.

This seems tricky :-(... I don't think we have information of device placement during graph construction and that's when we choose to do CloneGradient method. @piiswrong Any ideas how to work around that? Is there a device placement pass in NNVM that we could use for making a copy node (or any pass that knows about devices)?

PS: For anyone facing this issue, the workaround I am using is to reset _own_params after construction of the child.
import mxnet as mx

cell1 = mx.rnn.GRUCell(10)
seq1 = mx.rnn.SequentialRNNCell()
seq1.add(cell1)
cell2 = mx.rnn.GRUCell(10)
cell2._own_params = True  # Workaround
seq2 = mx.rnn.SequentialRNNCell(params=seq1.params)
seq2.add(cell2)
I think the issue is that, "with branch 1.7.0. We squashed all commits to avoid the huge .git folder." (from https://github.com/dmlc/cub) so the git hash recorded for the submodule no longer exists.
